message_2:
The energy of the gamma ray emitted during the decay of cesium-137 nucleus can be found by looking up the decay scheme of cesium-137. In this decay, cesium-137 (Cs-137) undergoes beta decay to form barium-137m (Ba-137m), which is a metastable nuclear isomer. The Ba-137m then undergoes gamma decay to reach its stable ground state (Ba-137).

The gamma ray emitted during this process has an energy of approximately 661.7 keV (kilo-electron volts). This value is a well-known and experimentally determined energy for the gamma ray emitted during the decay of Cs-137 to Ba-137m.
